Mahowald-Ravenel-Shick and Anick's fibration

Apr 1, 2019

In this paper, Mahowald, Ravenel, and Shick study a spectrum denoted in an approach meant to attack the telescope conjecture. In this post, I want to discuss this spectrum and its relation to this previous post. Let’s begin with the definition of : consider the map classifying ; then, there’s a map , and the Thom spectrum of the induced spherical bundle over is . After Definition 3.2 in their paper, MRS suggest that if exists, and , that there is an equivalence . (Recall that is a summand of for ; in particular, is a summand of .) In this post, I’d like to try to prove a version of this statement at .

Of course, exists at all primes, so you’d expect . The left hand side is the Thom spectrum of the map detecting , and the right hand side is the Thom spectrum of the map . There are maps and of spaces over . The latter is easy to construct: it is the adjoint to the composite of the inclusion of the bottom cell with the degree map . The former map is defined as follows: the map classifying factors through , by cellular approximation; therefore, you get a map of spaces over . What we obtain from this is a map of spaces over , and hence a map of Thom spectra.

OK, what about higher ? Note that the story we ran above for doesn’t work: is not a spherical Thom spectrum for . Indeed, suppose otherwise, and write . Then for some of degree zero. The -skeleton (resp. the -skeleton) of for odd (resp. ) is , so it suffices to show that there cannot exist a space for which . This is an easy consequence of unstability and the fact that (resp. ) in the cohomology of .

Can we at least define a map ? Let’s try instead to define a map . For this, we’ll induct on , using Beardsley’s paper, which exhibits as an -quotient of by a class of degree . Since is an -algebra, it suffices to show that is null in for all . This is true because the map is an equivalence up through (and including) dimension , and since is null in for all .

Note that will be homotopy commutative if is homotopy commutative. It turns out that this is true for : see this MathOverflow question. Unfortunately, will not be homotopy commutative in general. But that’s OK; one can interpret the previous paragraph as saying that the homotopy commutative map factors through .

Great; to get a map (note: not , which wouldn’t make sense at ), we now just need to show that vanish in the -series of , i.e., the “-bud” (i.e., formal group law up to degree ) of is of “height ”. The desired vanishing of now follows quickly from the complex orientability of , noting that the height of an -bud is defined when .

We’ve now got a candidate map which we’d like to show is an equivalence. Recall that , and that . It is not hard to see that the map is a mod homology isomorphism, and hence a -complete equivalence. Let’s note one interesting consequence.

Since is a summand of , which is equivalent to through dimension , there is an element . This pushes forward to an element . We can alternatively construct this element in the following manner: the EHP sequence defines a map , hence an element in . Note that the Thom spectrum of the map is . This is interesting: it’s saying that the “-quotient” of by (which is well-defined mod ) is .

Can we get an “integral” analogue of this result, perhaps something saying that the “-quotient” (in quotes because I don’t know if an -ring) of by “” (in quotes because is not canonical unless you kill ) is ? Let’s begin with the simplest case: . In this case, is actually a Thom spectrum: as we’ve already used above, it’s the Thom spectrum of the map . It’d be great if there was a map (detecting “”) whose Thom spectrum is . We’d obtain such a map if there was a fiber sequence . If this is a fiber sequence of loop maps, then this is the same as a fiber sequence , i.e., a fiber sequence . (Note that even constructing the map is not obvious: although you have an obvious map , this doesn’t canonically extend to a map from , because is not even a H-space!)

There are fiber sequences (obvious), (by looping the definition of as the fiber of the map ), (EHP), and (equivalent to the Hopf fibration ). These fit into a commutative square, and define for us the desired fiber sequence . We conclude that there is a (-local) map (detecting a class which deserves to be called “”) whose Thom spectrum is .

It turns out that all of this can be made to work -equivariantly. Here’s how the story goes. We know that the Thom spectrum of the map is . This gives two possible definitions of the equivariant analogue of : first, as the Thom spectrum of the induced bundle via the map , or as the Thom spectrum of the induced bundle via the map . Let’s call the resulting Thom spectra and ; it turns out that is actually -equivariantly equivalent to . The map is an equivalence through degree .

The spectrum is the free -ring with a nullhomotopy of the equivariant Hopf map . In other words, it is the Thom spectrum of the map . There’s an interesting comment to make here: , so is also the free -ring with a nullhomotopy of . More generally, one can define as a summand of . There are elements , and some of these live in . As before, (I think, if I’ve calculated correctly) we find that .

Now, consider the unit map , and let denote its fiber. Then the Thom spectrum of the map is . What we’d like to show is that there is a map whose Thom spectrum is also . This is true by the same argument as in the classical case, using the fiber sequence constructed via the fiber sequences , (EHP), and .

Let’s return back to this question of whether the “-quotient” of by “” is . As I said earlier, there are a few problems with this question: first, is even an -ring? Second, there’s no unique choice of . Nonetheless, we constructed, in the case when and , a fiber sequence , such that the induced map Thomifies to . More generally, there is a -local fiber sequence , given by patching together the fiber sequences (EHP), (definition), and (coming from the fiber sequence ; one can check that the fiber of the map above is indeed via the Serre spectral sequence). This fiber sequence gives a map which Thomifies to .

OK, now what? Recall that Beardsley constructs elements (all -localized) so that is the -quotient of by . This tells us that is the -quotient of by a map , i.e., is the Thom spectrum of a map . What we’d like is if there was a map — not a loop map, because I don’t know if that would make sense — Thomifying to .

We know that if is a fiber sequence and is a map, then there is a map , so this suggests a natural plan of attack: find a fiber sequence for some space , and a map whose Thom spectrum is . Delooping and rotating our desired fiber sequence tells us that we’d like a fiber sequence , with the first map inducing multiplication by on st homotopy groups.

Aha! There is in fact such a map after -localizing (for , which we’ll now adhere to) and ; our desired map is the special case . This comes from work of Cohen-Moore-Neisendorfer (there are lots of papers about this, but see, e.g., Theorem 8 here for a statement), where they prove that the map factors through the double suspension . For , the map is the same map we constructed above. In Problem 5(h) of the linked paper, Cohen-Moore-Neisendorfer ask if there is a fiber sequence (they also say that Toda had constructed such a fibration for , with ; I think this is the same fiber sequence as we wrote down a few paragraphs ago).

Their question was answered in the positive by Anick; see here. In the linked paper, Theriault shows that there is a space and a fiber sequence , where the first map induces multiplication by on st homotopy groups. (For instance, the result of Toda’s cited above says that , as we’d already observed.) Great; this means that we’re looking for a map whose Thom spectrum is .

I don’t know how to do this, but let’s grant ourselves some daydreaming time. Suppose that was actually an -ring, so to define , it suffices to define a map . In this paper (where is written for what is denoted as in this paper, the latter’s convention of which we are adopting), Theriault shows that if is a homotopy commutative and homotopy associative H-space, then any map (where denotes the mod Moore space with top cell in dimension , i.e., ) extends uniquely (up to homotopy) to a H-space map . If we also assume that is a homotopy commutative and homotopy associative H-space, then we’re reduced to defining a map . This in turn amounts to defining a map , i.e., an element such that kills this element.

(Update: According to the introduction here, Theriault’s result is apparently incorrect. Theorem B in Gray’s paper doesn’t work here, because is not -power torsion. I don’t know how to fix the suggested argument above. Let’s continue as though Theriault’s result is in fact correct.)

Now, I think it is true (proof: hearsay) that is in fact isomorphic to ; since we already know that Beardsley’s element lives in this degree, we find that is killed by , and that choosing defines the desired map . If denotes the induced map, then there’s a map from this Thom spectrum to (basically since is null in ), and I suspect that this is an isomorphism on mod homology, which implies by Whitehead that is in fact the -completion of the Thom spectrum of . To say this properly, we need to understand the homology of . (Recall that where , and that . A Serre spectral sequence calculation shows that , which implies after a small amount of calculation that the homology of indeed does the trick.)

Things seem to work out — modulo a few glaring issues: in the previous paragraph, we assumed that was an -ring, and that is a homotopy commutative and homotopy associative H-space (as well as Theriault’s apparently false result). (Note that if I asked for to be a loop space, I’d be in trouble: is not an -ring; see Example 1.4.28 here. These conditions are balanced precisely between the realm of being tantalizingly close to being true and impossibility.) I don’t know if these statements are true, but it’s good to know that the question we raised is related to possibly attack-able problems in the theory of structured ring spectra. How plausible are these statements? I don’t know how to address the question about , so let’s look at the question about being an -ring. Since is a summand of given by the Quillen idempotent, it suffices to show that the Quillen idempotent is an -ring map on . I don’t know how to show this, but see, e.g., Section 6 here, which briefly discusses this question. (Another, perhaps more minor, issue is that there’s a choice of extension of the map to , and we haven’t addressed this.)
